comment._content: I have been reliably informed that this is a motorcycle with a sidecar attached. Apparently there is a distinct difference.

comment.author: 33147718@N05

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I think we also see the chap in the white coat in the pic next door... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/10322309574/in/photostream/] You can tell they're motorcycle hooligans! They're wearing their caps back the front...not wearing ties either! The chap in the white coat looks a bit like Beatrice Kerr...a number of facial features look vaguely similar...particularly the ear lobes...per her ADB entry she had 3 brothers...maybe that's who we're looking at here... OK petrolheads...what make is it?...what's the production date?... My guess is it's a pre WW1 model...?1913-14...looks a bit like the BSA stripe and insignia on the side of the petrol tank...however, I can't find an early BSA with this cylinder arrangement...looks like a V-twin?...maybe from a Matchless...Enfield etc? ...the front end of this New Hudson looks very similar...but per Wikipedia they appear to have come with a single cylinder J.A.P. engine at this time museumvictoria.com.au/collections/items/772722/negative-n... ...the dog in this one looks similar museumvictoria.com.au/collections/items/772746/negative-m... www.bonhams.com/auctions/18221/lot/399/ this link mightn't be around for long...it's a fantastic pic of a 1913 Zenith with a JAP V-twin engine...quite a few similarities... www.sunbeamsidevalve.com/new_page_7.14.htm also quite a few similarities with this 1914 Sunbeam...particularly the fitting on the frame above the petrol tank (tyre pump?)...one of the 1913 models also evidently came with a JAP V-twin...can't yet find any pics of the 1913 model...looks like Sunbeam made a standard model for church warderns and a slightly more powerful V-twin for the adventurous...alas the insignia on the petrol tank doesn't match up with the Sunbeam...I'm beginning to think we're looking at a custom made affair, with say a Sunbeam frame, a BSA petrol tank, a JAP V-twin engine...there are people around who know all this stuff backwards (in their sleep)...so I might leave the issue of identifying the motorcycle to one of them...but my bet is the pedigree is English...it doesn't look like an Indian, Harley Davidson, or Excelsior...(US makes) www.go-faster.com/VeteranMotorcycles1914.html 'complete list' of motorcycles on the UK market in 1914 ...my guess is the location might be inner Melbourne...if this were the Kerr brothers, then given the logistics of carrying a camera around, I suspect the pic might have been taken near the family home... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] ???maybe other pics/items in the Beatrice Kerr collection might shed some light on this pic...eg. pics known to be of her brothers...or perhaps a few old motorcycle parts...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I think it might be Charles Kerr, driving, also seen in this image: His address on enlistment is given as 39 Dinsdale St Albert Park, which is also the address for his mother. This image could well have been taken on Dinsdale st! Looks a bit different these days :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Ha! good one!...looks like him...matching ears! Plus, a motor cyclist in the Flying Corps makes sense...per the AWM records he was 31 years of age when he enlisted in 1916...occupation engineer (mechanical presumably...maybe why they wanted him in the Flying Corps).

Location still a work in progress!

Identity and DOB of motorcycle, ditto! Might have to send  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] off to Melbourne to track down the rego details...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] on closer inspection, I'm now convinced this pic was taken outside/near 39 Dinsdale St, looking up the street to the right...If we take one of Mr Google's wonderful and exciting street view tours, you can see that the dividing wall on the side of 36 Dinsdale St matches up exactly with what we see here...check out the wall near the palm tree...Looks like the ornamental ironwork we see on 34 Dinsdale St is still there as well... View Larger Map

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [a bit later] nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1592609 Argus 25/1/1917, p. 2...for sale notice column 4: 'Triumph, free engine, absolutely perfect, late model; must sell to-day; cheap. 39 Dinsdale st. Albert Park' So! Unless the lads had a fleet of motorcycles, chances are we're looking at a Triumph...the stripe on the petrol tank matches...along with quite a few other features...can't yet find a pic of one quite like this...if I'm allowed to update my last guess, I now think it's a bit later than a 1913 model... IF it's the same motorcycle (still highly theoretical)...and it was sold (?or repossessed if it wasn't), then at least we've got 1917 as an end date!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: Wonderful stuff [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02], we're super excited! That wall is a clincher :) I think we will be able to identify the other men too from some upcoming photos. The records for these images are looking much healthier indeed :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
